headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. And thank you for joining us. Today, we'll discuss Reynolds American's results for the 2010 Fourth Quarter and Full Year as well as our outlook for 2011. We'll focus our discussion on adjusted results as management believes this better refle
componenttext:
Good morning. And thank you for joining us. Today, we'll discuss Reynolds American's results for the 2010 Fourth Quarter and Full Year as well as our outlook for 2011. We'll focus our discussion on adjusted results as management believes this better reflects the underlying business performance. A reconciliation of adjusted to reported earnings is on our press release, which is on our website at reynoldsamerican.com.
Joining me this morning are RAI's President and CEO, Susan Ivey; Dan Delen, RAI's President and CEO-elect; and Tom Adams, our CFO.
The information we're about to discuss includes forward-looking statements. When we talk about future results or events, a number of factors could generate results materially different from our projections today. These factors include, but are not limited to, items detailed in our press release and SEC filings. Except as provided by federal securities laws, we're not required to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Susan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased to report that RAI finished up a strong year with excellent performance across its operating companies. As our results show, both of our reportable business segments delivered additional volume and share gains on k
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased to report that RAI finished up a strong year with excellent performance across its operating companies. As our results show, both of our reportable business segments delivered additional volume and share gains on key brands in the fourth quarter, and this drove increases in adjusted earnings and margin.
For the full year, R.J. Reynolds and American Snuff continued to generate profitable growth despite ongoing weakness in consumer spending and continued competitive activity. 
In addition, Santa Fe had another great year, delivering double-digit growth in both volume and earnings. In fact, the company's Natural American Spirit brand delivered growth on every style and in every state last year. This successful performance demonstrates, not just the fundamental strength of our operating company's key brand, but also the effective execution of their business strategies. And RAI continued to deliver outstanding value to our shareholders in 2010, with a dividend increase of 8.9% and a two-for-one stock split. We also announced an increase in our dividend payout target to 80%, which further demonstrates our commitment to returning value to shareholders.
As you know, this is my last earnings call before I retire at the end of this month. It's been a pleasure and a privilege to lead this company for the past 6 1/2 years. And I've enjoyed working with and getting to know so many of you in the financial community. Given RAI's tremendous achievements over this period and its current positive momentum, I am confident that great things lie ahead for this company and for its talented people. As we've demonstrated over the years, we'll continue to deliver on our commitments to all of our stakeholders.
And now, I'd like to hand the call over to Dan who will give you a closer look at our 2010 performance.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan, and hello, everyone. As you've just heard, our operating companies delivered strong fourth quarter and full-year results driven by gains in volume and share on key brands, as well as improved pricing and efficiencies. I'm pleased to repo
componenttext:
Thank you, Susan, and hello, everyone. As you've just heard, our operating companies delivered strong fourth quarter and full-year results driven by gains in volume and share on key brands, as well as improved pricing and efficiencies. I'm pleased to report that R.J. Reynolds cigarette brand portfolio strategy is working extremely well with gains on growth brands continuing to offset declines on the company's other cigarette brands.
As you know, we made a decision some time back to de-emphasize and eliminate our private label brands in order to reduce complexity. Excluding those brands, R.J. Reynolds' total cigarette market share in the fourth quarter increased by a full share point to 28.1%. Even factoring in the declining private label brands, the company's total cigarette market share was 28.3%, down just 0.02 of a percentage point. This holds true for the full year as well. 
Total 2010 cigarette market share was 28.1%, down 0.02 of a percentage point from the prior year. But excluding the private label brands, its market share was up 0.07 of a percentage point at 27.5%. 
Both of R.J. Reynolds growth brands, Camel and Pall Mall, played major roles in the company's strong performance. Combined growth brand market share increased 2.9 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 16.2%. And these two brands accounted for more than 55% of R.J. Reynolds' total volume. 
Camel's fourth quarter cigarette market share increased by 0.06 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter to 8%. This is the brand's highest market share in more than 40 years. And for the full year, Camel's market share rose 0.02 of a percentage point to 7.7%. Camel's improving share and demographics continue to benefit from growing consumer interest in its menthol styles. These styles use capsule technologies to offer adult smokers more fresh menthol flavor on demand, a unique product point of difference over competitive menthol brands. Also enhancing the brand’s performance in the growing menthol category is Camel Crush, which uses the same technology to offer the option of regular or menthol with each cigarette. 
Including Camel Crush, Camel's menthol market share jumped by 0.07 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter to 2.1%. Camel is also performing well as a total tobacco brand with further equity building and refinements to its innovative more modern smoke-free tobacco products. 
Camel SNUS continue to perform well even with lower levels of promotional support, and its performance is being enhanced by two new styles, Robust and Winterchill that were added in the third quarter. These larger cost products offer adult tobacco consumers a richer, more full body tobacco taste as well as smoke-free and spit-free convenience.
In Camel's new line of dissolvable tobacco products, Camel Orbs, Sticks, and Strips have received product and packaging upgrades and will be introduced in two new lead markets in March.
Now turning to R.J. Reynolds' other growth brand, Pall Mall. By all measures, Pall Mall had an outstanding year. As the nation's fastest growing major cigarette brand, Pall Mall increased its fourth quarter market share by 2.3 percentage points to 8.3%. And for the full year, Pall Mall gained 2.7 percentage points to 7.4%. And that's the brand's highest market share since 1975. 
Trial and conversion to Pall Mall continue to increase while promotional levels remained steady. For value-conscious adult smokers, Pall Mall offers a meaningful product point of difference from other value brands by delivering a high-quality, longer lasting cigarette at an affordable price. That's a true value proposition.
Another driver of performance at R.J. Reynolds is their continued focus on productivity improvement. This ongoing process is making the company much more efficient and focused while freeing up resources in invest in growth for the long term. And even though they've already made great strides on this front, there's still more to come. 
R.J. Reynolds has dramatically reduced its product offerings and by doing so, it's also driving down complexity. The company ended the year with less than 150 SKUs, a reduction that represents four out of every five of the SKUs that has held back in 2004, and they plan further reductions in 2011. 
The company is also in the process of further improving its cigarette manufacturing efficiencies with a consolidation of three facilities into its largest factory at Tobaccoville. As a result of this move, the company has offered buyouts to members of the manufacturing workforce to better align resources with production needs. 
Additionally, R.J. Reynolds plans to build a new R&D annex at its Tobaccoville manufacturing center with constructions starting this summer. This will be a smaller, more modern facility that will better meet the company's future needs. 
As you know, R.J. Reynolds recently expanded its field trade marketing organization to serve American Snuff. This transition has gone extremely well and we're already starting to reap the benefits of this change.
So, R.J. Reynolds has made substantial progress on many fronts this year. And this demonstrates the growing momentum that positions the company well in the coming year and far into the future.
Turning to American Snuff. The company finished the year on a very strong note with higher moist-snuff pricing and volume, driving gains in adjusted operating income and share for both the fourth quarter and the full year. American Snuff's first half of the year was especially challenging, with high levels of competitive promotional activity and value-priced line extensions, as well as declines in the roll-your-own and other non-core tobacco products, following increased federal excise taxes. 
However, the company made up substantial ground as it moved through the year with equity enhancements to the Grizzly brand driving that growth. The company's total fourth quarter moist-snuff consumer offtake share increased to 31.3%, a gain of 0.08 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter. The company believes this measure better reflects the actual brand performance. 
For the full year, American Snuff's total moist-snuff consumer offtake share was 30.4%. Grizzly, American Snuff's flagship brand, continued its positive momentum in the fourth quarter with its share of consumer offtake reaching another record high of 27.2%. The brand continues to benefit from the packaging upgrades to embossed metal lids in the second quarter. And the recent field trade-marketing change is also contributing to the improved performance. 
House products continue to be the fastest growing styles in moist-snuff and jumped more than 20% in 2010. Grizzly's Pouches are performing extremely well. Grizzly captured more than 24% of all Pouch sales in the fourth quarter and has the number one Wintergreen Pouch product in the category.
So as we expected, American Snuff delivered solid gains in volume and earnings, driven by strong performance in the second half of the year. Even as price gaps to premium continue to narrow. And this momentum positions the company for further gains this year.
That rounds out the year's successful business performance at RAI's operating companies. Now Tom will provide some financial details. Tom?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan, and good morning. During my discussion, I'll focus primarily on adjusted results to provide perspective on our underlying business performance. Reconciliations of adjusted to reported results are in our press release, which is available on
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan, and good morning. During my discussion, I'll focus primarily on adjusted results to provide perspective on our underlying business performance. Reconciliations of adjusted to reported results are in our press release, which is available on our website. Now, let's take a look at the fourth quarter and full year.
RAI's fourth quarter adjusted earnings per share increased 9% to $0.60 per share. These adjusted results, exclude charges of $0.05 per share in non-cash goodwill impairment charges related to the proposed sale of Lane Limited and related assets, as well as trademark impairment charges for American Snuff Taylor's Pride loose-leaf tobacco brand. These adjusted results also exclude $0.02 per share in cost primarily related to plant closings and the expansion of R.J. Reynolds’ field trade-marketing organization.
On a reported basis, RAI's fourth quarter EPS was $0.53 per share, up 43% from the prior year quarter. And for the full year, adjusted EPS was $2.49 per share, up 7% from the prior year. Full-year adjusted results exclude the previously referenced charges and costs, as well as charges for changes in federal health care laws and Canadian government settlements.
On a reported basis, full-year EPS was $1.90 per share, up 15% from the prior year. RAI's adjusted operating margin increased significantly in both the fourth quarter and for the full year. For 2010, margin increased 1.3 percentage points to 29.8%, boosted by higher pricing growth brand gains and productivity improvements at our operating companies.
Now turning to R.J. Reynolds' performance. R.J. Reynolds' fourth quarter adjusted operating income increased 5.5% from the prior year quarter to $514 million, benefiting from higher cigarette pricing and growth-brand volume gains. The company also delivered additional promotional efficiencies and productivity improvements. For the full year, adjusted operating income rose 4.4% to $2.12 billion. R.J. Reynolds also saw gains in its fourth quarter adjusted operating margin, which increased 2.4 percentage points to 29.1%. For the full year, R.J. Reynolds' adjusted operating margin increased to 28.9%.
Turning to cigarette shipment volume. R.J. Reynolds' fourth quarter cigarette shipment volume declined 5.1%, but excluding private label brands, was down just 1.9%. That compares well to the industry volume decline of 4.7%. Over the full year, the company's cigarette shipment volume was also down 5.1%, but again when private label brands are excluded, the company's volume was down only 2.1%, that compares favorably with an industry decline of 3.8%.
So that's a brief review of R.J. Reynolds' key results. 
Now let's turn to American Snuff. The company delivered outstanding growth in the fourth quarter with adjusted operating income increasing 23.5% from the prior year quarter to $103 million. This was driven by higher pricing and moist-snuff volume growth. And for the full year, adjusted operating income rose 6.1% from the prior year period to $374 million. 
American Snuff's fourth quarter adjusted operating margin rose 2.2 percentage points from the prior-year quarter to 53.9%. And for the full year, adjusted operating margin of 52% was down slightly from the prior year primarily due to excise tax-related declines in roll-your-own and other non-core tobacco products. 
Turning to moist-snuff volume. The company's total fourth quarter shipment volume grew 8.2% and was up 5.8% for the full year. So American Snuff showed great resilience and good momentum in the second half of the year, which positions it well for the year ahead. As a result of the strong performance by our operating companies, Reynolds American has delivered outstanding value in the past year, generating a total shareholder return of over 31%, more than double that of the S&P 500. And we will continue to evaluate additional opportunities to enhance value for our investors. 
Turning to our balance sheet. Reynolds American ended the year with cash balances of $2.2 billion after the company contributed an additional $500 million to the pension plans in the fourth quarter. That brought total pension contributions to $800 million for the year putting RAI in a well-funded position. With the repayment of $300 million in debt in July, our leverage ratio further improved to a strong 1.5x debt-to-EBITDA. 
With the proposed sale of the Lane business, we'll be adding approximately $200 million in cash to the balance sheet while further reducing complexity and streamlining American Snuff's operations.
And now I'll close with our guidance for 2011. Based on RAI's excellent results and given the solid momentum on key brands and productivity efforts at our operating companies, we expect full-year EPS in the range of $2.60 to $2.70. I would note that this guidance assumes that the sale of Lane is completed in the first half of this year.
Thank you. And we'll now turn to the Q&A portion of the call. Latoya, would you remind our callers how to get into the queue?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Our next question is from Vivien Azer of Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Our next question is from Vivien Azer of Citigroup.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: My first question has to do with Camel. And the market share gains in the quarter were really terrific. And I was wondering if you could offer any color in terms of – kind of the pricing trends for the brand either on an absolute basis or relative to ke
componenttext: My first question has to do with Camel. And the market share gains in the quarter were really terrific. And I was wondering if you could offer any color in terms of – kind of the pricing trends for the brand either on an absolute basis or relative to key competitors?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the perspective on this, Vivien, is that really throughout the year, we've made sort of sequential gains in terms of pricing. And really, our pricing is up more than the industry throughout 2010. And  So we are particularly pleased on Camel that w
componenttext: I think the perspective on this, Vivien, is that really throughout the year, we've made sort of sequential gains in terms of pricing. And really, our pricing is up more than the industry throughout 2010. And  So we are particularly pleased on Camel that we've been able to grow market share during the year ending in the fourth quarter with 8 share points on Camel, which is up 0.6 year-on-year. But at the same time, also the financial progress that we've made, where we've been able to increase revenues and margins.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just thinking kind of to 2011, can you offer any color in terms of your outlook for the cigarette industry in terms of volumes. And also, your expectations for state excise taxes?
componenttext: And just thinking kind of to 2011, can you offer any color in terms of your outlook for the cigarette industry in terms of volumes. And also, your expectations for state excise taxes?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes I think for 2011, we really would see the industry cigarette volume to be very similar to 2010, down around 4%. And then moist-snuff as well, I think also similar to 2010, we would see an increase there in the 6% to 7% range. So I think really, when w
componenttext: Yes I think for 2011, we really would see the industry cigarette volume to be very similar to 2010, down around 4%. And then moist-snuff as well, I think also similar to 2010, we would see an increase there in the 6% to 7% range. So I think really, when we look about, across both categories, pretty steady as she goes. I think that's extremely positive and a positive backdrop to our business looking forward.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of state excise taxes, kind of same as last year or bearish?
componenttext: In terms of state excise taxes, kind of same as last year or bearish?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: In 2010, we had around $0.085 increase, and for next year, we would expect that to be somewhere in the $0.15 to $0.20 range.
componenttext: In 2010, we had around $0.085 increase, and for next year, we would expect that to be somewhere in the $0.15 to $0.20 range.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And my last question has to do with cost savings for 2011. Clearly you guys are doing a lot of work and with the employee buyouts that you've offered, can you just remind us what you're looking for in terms of the comp savings for the upcoming year?
componenttext: And my last question has to do with cost savings for 2011. Clearly you guys are doing a lot of work and with the employee buyouts that you've offered, can you just remind us what you're looking for in terms of the comp savings for the upcoming year?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think really I'd maybe give a little bit of color on this side. Of course we have a lot of ongoing productivity savings within our company. It's really become a way of life here at the company, and we have ongoing programs all the time. And I think
componenttext: Yes, I think really I'd maybe give a little bit of color on this side. Of course we have a lot of ongoing productivity savings within our company. It's really become a way of life here at the company, and we have ongoing programs all the time. And I think the key way that we really track performance on this is through our operating margins to make sure that what actual savings we generate actually hit the bottom line. I'm very pleased to report that RJR had strong operating margin growth both for the year in 2010 and for the quarter. For the year, it hit 28.9%, that's up 1.2 percentage points. And for the quarter, it hit 29.1%, which is up a full 2.4 percentage points. And so really that's the way we track to make sure that not only are we generating savings on individual programs, but that it really shows up on the bottom line.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Andrew Kieley of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Andrew Kieley of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Susan or Dan, I wonder first if, could you talk about any market share, long-term market share objectives you have in cigarettes? Are there firm targets you have? Is it just enough to grow the share of the focused brands or are you more interested in over
componenttext: Susan or Dan, I wonder first if, could you talk about any market share, long-term market share objectives you have in cigarettes? Are there firm targets you have? Is it just enough to grow the share of the focused brands or are you more interested in overall share growth? Could you talk about anything there?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes I think obviously, we can't and we don't guide on specific market share numbers going forward. But I think the best way to kind of provide a little bit of color and a little bit perspective on this, the way we track our business is to look at our mark
componenttext: Yes I think obviously, we can't and we don't guide on specific market share numbers going forward. But I think the best way to kind of provide a little bit of color and a little bit perspective on this, the way we track our business is to look at our market share in cigarettes at R.J. Reynolds. And to look at that x private label. In private label we’ve largely gone out and announce the delisting of almost all those styles in that segment. So we really track market share performance on an x private-label basis. I'm happy to report that over the last years, we've seen a progressive growing trend on that basis within our business. So I think if we look at history that way, I think we're quite confident that we can repeat that in the future.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Secondly, can you talk a bit about the pricing and the promotional environment in the premium cigarette category for 2011? Was there anything unusual in terms of timing of your promotions or pricing increases in cigarettes in the fourth quarter? Because g
componenttext: Secondly, can you talk a bit about the pricing and the promotional environment in the premium cigarette category for 2011? Was there anything unusual in terms of timing of your promotions or pricing increases in cigarettes in the fourth quarter? Because growth of price mix was a little bit lower than it had been through the previous quarters in 2010?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we saw an industry price increase, which we obviously took as well in the fourth quarter. Those things normally take a few weeks to kind of settle in as they work through the supply chain. But actually we were happy with the, sort of sequent
componenttext: Well, I think we saw an industry price increase, which we obviously took as well in the fourth quarter. Those things normally take a few weeks to kind of settle in as they work through the supply chain. But actually we were happy with the, sort of sequential pricing gains throughout the year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just last question, could you talk a bit about how management would evaluate a share repurchase at some point? And are there any near-term cash uses we should be thinking about early in 2011 that would prevent that in terms of pension funding or anything
componenttext: Just last question, could you talk a bit about how management would evaluate a share repurchase at some point? And are there any near-term cash uses we should be thinking about early in 2011 that would prevent that in terms of pension funding or anything else?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: As Susan said in her remarks, we increased our dividend last year. We split the stock, we increased our payout ratio from 75% to 80%. So we used dividends as our primary source to return value to our shareholders, that and to the rest of our share price,
componenttext: As Susan said in her remarks, we increased our dividend last year. We split the stock, we increased our payout ratio from 75% to 80%. So we used dividends as our primary source to return value to our shareholders, that and to the rest of our share price, of course. Much like last year, I mean, we're continuing to build out facilities to make them FDA-compliant and for capacity at American Snuff, as Dan mentioned we'll be spending some money on a new R&D annex out of Tobaccoville. So CapEx next year is going to be roughly in the same range as what we saw this year. We got some debt coming due next year while our pension plans are about 90% funded. There may be an opportunity to put a little bit more in at the end of the year. We'll just have to see how the returns and the plans are. And having said all that, I mean I think there may be an opportunity to do some additional things, and certainly share repurchase is one of the things that we discussed with our Board of Directors.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Adelman of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Adelman of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can we revisit the issue about pricing in the fourth quarter? Your principal competitors' net pricing year-on-year, the increase was fairly consistent through the fourth quarter. And yours moderated despite the fact that your mix got better. So when you l
componenttext: Can we revisit the issue about pricing in the fourth quarter? Your principal competitors' net pricing year-on-year, the increase was fairly consistent through the fourth quarter. And yours moderated despite the fact that your mix got better. So when you look at how you operated the business, do you think you became more price-oriented in the fourth quarter? Did you make an intentional decision to go a bit more for share than you did earlier in the year?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think, really, the way I would look at this, David, is kind of if you're looking at the year-on-year, quarter-to-quarter kind of compare, I would say that in the fourth quarter of 2009, we were probably a little bit uncompetitive in the quarter, vis-a-v
componenttext: I think, really, the way I would look at this, David, is kind of if you're looking at the year-on-year, quarter-to-quarter kind of compare, I would say that in the fourth quarter of 2009, we were probably a little bit uncompetitive in the quarter, vis-a-vis the volume side. I think if we look at 2010, I think we were happy with the performance and happy with where we stood from a competitive point of view. And then of course, I would also just say that the price increase that happened, that took a little while to work through the supply chain to actually see that reflected. And so really, I'm quite pleased with our performance both for pricing and mix point of view during the quarter.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then Dan on the cost side in this Cigarette business, typically you see your per-pack costs go up somewhat sequentially. This year, they came down sequentially. And I'm just curious, were there specific material cost savings efforts that had a increme
componenttext: And then Dan on the cost side in this Cigarette business, typically you see your per-pack costs go up somewhat sequentially. This year, they came down sequentially. And I'm just curious, were there specific material cost savings efforts that had a incremental impact in the fourth quarter?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think, David, really nothing specific comes to mind. But really for us, we look at this day in and day out throughout the whole company. And I think probably what you're noticing in our numbers is just that dedication to this whole cost equation to bein
componenttext: I think, David, really nothing specific comes to mind. But really for us, we look at this day in and day out throughout the whole company. And I think probably what you're noticing in our numbers is just that dedication to this whole cost equation to being as efficient and effective as we can be with every dollar spent, just coming in throughout the numbers and throughout the company.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then at American Snuff, if you think about the competitive operating environment in the fourth quarter and then coming into the first quarter, are you envisioning somewhat higher levels of competitive activity given some of the new product activity th
componenttext: And then at American Snuff, if you think about the competitive operating environment in the fourth quarter and then coming into the first quarter, are you envisioning somewhat higher levels of competitive activity given some of the new product activity that will be there?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you really provide a little bit perspective. I think Grizzly is a brand that's really shown over time, that it is -- it's got a very strong equity. And of course, we continue to invest in that equity over time. And of particular note there during
componenttext: I think you really provide a little bit perspective. I think Grizzly is a brand that's really shown over time, that it is -- it's got a very strong equity. And of course, we continue to invest in that equity over time. And of particular note there during 2010, was the metal lid upgrade that came in the second quarter, that really helped drive growth and equity-based growth over time. And really the field-force expansion at the back end of the year. Those were the big things that sort of got the brand back on track. Now of course, it's a competitive category, and there are always going to be people and competitors doing pricing moves within the category. But I think really as a company, we're focused on continuing to drive the equity of Grizzly over time and very pleased with its performance and how resilient it's been under some of those competitive threat.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, is any there any update you can provide on the MSA arbitration process either in terms of the likely timing of a resolution on this first arbitrated year? And any clarity as to when there might be a resolution of that?
componenttext: And then lastly, is any there any update you can provide on the MSA arbitration process either in terms of the likely timing of a resolution on this first arbitrated year? And any clarity as to when there might be a resolution of that?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think when we take a look at the MSA, I think this is a continuing process. There's nothing really of particular note that's new. I think the next sort of major meetings of that are in April so early in the second quarter on that front. And we just need
componenttext: I think when we take a look at the MSA, I think this is a continuing process. There's nothing really of particular note that's new. I think the next sort of major meetings of that are in April so early in the second quarter on that front. And we just need to work through the process of this arbitration, which as you know is quite a complicated and involved process.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Christine Farkas of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Christine Farkas of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the margin step up or the margin increase in the quarter, I'm wondering if I can perhaps ask, how much were your cost savings in the quarter or for the year? Did you disclose that?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the margin step up or the margin increase in the quarter, I'm wondering if I can perhaps ask, how much were your cost savings in the quarter or for the year? Did you disclose that?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Christine, this is Tom. We haven't disclosed that as Dan said that, that's kind of built in to the operating run rate, and we really measure it on the increases in margin over time. And while we've announced a couple of restructurings, I mean there's many
componenttext: Christine, this is Tom. We haven't disclosed that as Dan said that, that's kind of built in to the operating run rate, and we really measure it on the increases in margin over time. And while we've announced a couple of restructurings, I mean there's many, many things that are going on in the company simultaneously, not top-down driven, but basically coming up through the ranks where people are very mindful about how they spend the dollars for the company. So it's just invested in the DNA of the company at this point.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So just on the back of that, given the net pricing was lighter this quarter than we've seen in other quarters, yet the margin expansion was so tremendous, there's nothing in your mind that sticks out with respect to timing of cost savings in the fourth qu
componenttext: So just on the back of that, given the net pricing was lighter this quarter than we've seen in other quarters, yet the margin expansion was so tremendous, there's nothing in your mind that sticks out with respect to timing of cost savings in the fourth quarter?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, there's not.
componenttext: No, there's not.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Then my second question has to do with the private label volumes. You've indicated the big difference in growth and share with or without the private label volumes. Is there a time where we cycle this completely or is it just ongoing slowdown of those vol
componenttext: Then my second question has to do with the private label volumes. You've indicated the big difference in growth and share with or without the private label volumes. Is there a time where we cycle this completely or is it just ongoing slowdown of those volumes so that we'll feel a normalized moderation of that? Or will we cycle this in a particular quarter to see the jump in or change in volume trends?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Christine. I think last quarter we still had 0.2 to 0.3 market share points left in private label. And I think really the third quarter will have cycled through this by then. So we'll still see some vestiges of that in the first quarter, second quart
componenttext: Yes, Christine. I think last quarter we still had 0.2 to 0.3 market share points left in private label. And I think really the third quarter will have cycled through this by then. So we'll still see some vestiges of that in the first quarter, second quarter, but really be clean by the third.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ann Gurkin of Davenport.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ann Gurkin of Davenport.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to start with MST [moist smokeless tobacco]. Can we just get an update on the build-up of the new facility in Tennessee that's still going to open in early 2012?
componenttext: I want to start with MST [moist smokeless tobacco]. Can we just get an update on the build-up of the new facility in Tennessee that's still going to open in early 2012?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: What's the estimated capacity utilization of that facility when it opens?
componenttext: What's the estimated capacity utilization of that facility when it opens?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well the facility physically, obviously, has plenty of room for expansion. But each of the lines within the facility, that's modular. So as your volume grows, you can add lines as you want. So we're actually expecting a high utilization rate as we open. B
componenttext: Well the facility physically, obviously, has plenty of room for expansion. But each of the lines within the facility, that's modular. So as your volume grows, you can add lines as you want. So we're actually expecting a high utilization rate as we open. But have plenty of physical room to expand as required given that the moist-snuff, our volumes are growing over time.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then I'm hearing a little bit of growing concern that there might be -- the bottom and the very low end of the MST market might be opening up to a low, low, low-price brand coming in there. Is there any concern that, that gap is getting to wide? In ot
componenttext: And then I'm hearing a little bit of growing concern that there might be -- the bottom and the very low end of the MST market might be opening up to a low, low, low-price brand coming in there. Is there any concern that, that gap is getting to wide? In other words, is Grizzly's price getting too high to open up that lower end? I don't know if you can comment on that.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think on that front, I'm actually quite pleased with the competitive position that Grizzly has in the marketplace. I really believe it's much more than just a price-driven proposition. We have a great product inside the can. We have a significant ma
componenttext: No, I think on that front, I'm actually quite pleased with the competitive position that Grizzly has in the marketplace. I really believe it's much more than just a price-driven proposition. We have a great product inside the can. We have a significant marketing and equity investment in the brand. And I believe that it can continue to grow as we move forward based on that.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you all changing the way you approach the market or your business giving the potential for the TPSAC [Tobacco Products Scientific Advisory Committee] ruling, March 23?
componenttext: Are you all changing the way you approach the market or your business giving the potential for the TPSAC [Tobacco Products Scientific Advisory Committee] ruling, March 23?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think for us, it's really steady as she goes. Of course we're adapting our business model to the reality of regulation as it exists through the FDA. But really, no specific things at this time in terms of adjusting to that potential sort of headline ris
componenttext: I think for us, it's really steady as she goes. Of course we're adapting our business model to the reality of regulation as it exists through the FDA. But really, no specific things at this time in terms of adjusting to that potential sort of headline risk that might exist in March.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Rae Maile from JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Rae Maile from JP Morgan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was looking back at some old stuff that I read about Reynolds on the day when RJR announced the transaction. And you managed to take the market cap from a little over $6 billion to almost $19 billion. So I think that's a very worthy point to wish you an
componenttext: I was looking back at some old stuff that I read about Reynolds on the day when RJR announced the transaction. And you managed to take the market cap from a little over $6 billion to almost $19 billion. So I think that's a very worthy point to wish you and Russell a very long and a very happy return. And thank you for all very good times along the way. Best of luck, Susan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is actually Tyler filling in for Judy. I just had two quick questions. The first just on Pall Mall. And I'd just be interested to hear your commentary on that just given the solid growth over the past few years, but a little bit more of that kind of
componenttext: This is actually Tyler filling in for Judy. I just had two quick questions. The first just on Pall Mall. And I'd just be interested to hear your commentary on that just given the solid growth over the past few years, but a little bit more of that kind of the value of marketing aspect? And just how you -- how we should think about that -- that Pall Mall's prospects really after, once we do see the macros continue to improve and maybe unemployment getting a bit better and kind of how you guys think about the prospects for the brand in that type of environment?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think Pall Mall has obviously had a great run over the last couple of years. It, in the fourth quarter, actually hit 8.3 market share points. And I think Pall Mall, in my mind, very similar to all our brands in all the operating companies is really a di
componenttext: I think Pall Mall has obviously had a great run over the last couple of years. It, in the fourth quarter, actually hit 8.3 market share points. And I think Pall Mall, in my mind, very similar to all our brands in all the operating companies is really a differentiated proposition. And it is not just a pure price play. It's really got a product differentiation as part of their mix. Of course, it's a brand with historic equity in the market as well. And we continue to invest in a different way, but in the equity of the brand as well. And this all comes back to that product differentiation where it's a longer-lasting cigarette, more puffs per cigarette. So yes, pricing might be the trial, the thing that gets the consumer to try it out of the gate, but actually they stick with it because it's a very unique product in the market and differentiated. So looking forward, I think even if some of the macro-economic trends in the country change, I believe that the proposition is still correct for the consumers, and we can continue to grow whether the economy's going well or not going so well. And I would also remind you that prior to this latest economic downturn, the brand already was growing even when the economy was doing extremely well.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just my last question is in regards to TPSAC, FDA and I was just wondering if you could provide any color or commentary in regards to, what do you think could happen to volumes if there was an actual menthol ban?
componenttext: Just my last question is in regards to TPSAC, FDA and I was just wondering if you could provide any color or commentary in regards to, what do you think could happen to volumes if there was an actual menthol ban?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well let me start by saying is I don't believe a menthol ban is imminent. I think the TPSAC obviously is going to make its recommendations here at the back end of March. But just to remind everybody, that is just a recommendation at this stage. And then w
componenttext: Well let me start by saying is I don't believe a menthol ban is imminent. I think the TPSAC obviously is going to make its recommendations here at the back end of March. But just to remind everybody, that is just a recommendation at this stage. And then we'll need to see what the FDA actually decides to do based on whatever recommendation comes out of the advisory committee. So I think given that we don't have a specific direction from the FDA, how they might want to act, I think it's a little bit premature to speculate as to how sort of competitive positions or volumes and different segments might settle in, in the market place.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Morris Moore, Head of Investor Relations.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning and thank you for joining us. Today, we'll discuss Reynolds American's first quarter results, as well as our outlook for the full year. We'll focus our discussion on adjusted results as management believes this better reflects the underlying
componenttext:
Good morning and thank you for joining us. Today, we'll discuss Reynolds American's first quarter results, as well as our outlook for the full year. We'll focus our discussion on adjusted results as management believes this better reflects the underlying business performance.
A reconciliation of reported to adjusted earnings is on our press release, which is on our website at reynoldsamerican.com.
With me this morning are RAI's President and CEO, Dan Delen; and Tom Adams, our CFO.
The information we're about to discuss includes forward-looking statements. When we talk about future results or events, a number of factors could generate results materially different from our projections today. These factors include, but are not limited to, items detailed in our press release and SEC filings. Except as provided by Federal Securities Laws, we're not required to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Dan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased to be with you today, and share with you some of the insights and results at Reynolds American and its operating companies. As our results show, RAI and it's operating company turn it over the first quarter, giving
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased to be with you today, and share with you some of the insights and results at Reynolds American and its operating companies. As our results show, RAI and it's operating company turn it over the first quarter, giving us a solid foundation for growth in the year ahead.
As you can see from the positive results across our companies, RAI's initiative to transform tobacco continues to gain momentum. RAI delivers higher adjusted earnings and margin, driven by additional volume and share gains on all our operating companies key brands, as well as higher pricing and further productivity improvements. Both of our reportable business segments, R.J. Reynolds and American Snuff, continue to execute their business strategy extremely well, and this is reflected by further improvement in their marketplace and financial performance.
And once again, performance was strong in Santa Fe, with higher volume, share and earnings in the first quarter. Two of our highlights I'd like to touch on, Reynolds American continued to deliver value to our shareholders with a further dividend increase of 8.2% in February, bringing it in line with RAI's revised 80% dividend payout target. I would also note that RAI successfully closed the sale Of Lane, Limited  subsidiary in February. This allows RAI's operating companies to focus our energy resources of the primary growth categories within their businesses.
This continued transformation of our operating companies business and our focus on providing innovative tobacco products to meet changing consumer preferences positions RAI well for long-term success. As we reported today, RAI is reaffirming its guidance, and we expect full-year adjusted EPS growth in the mid-to-high single digits, excluding charges related to plant closings and tax items.
Before I turn to our operating perform, I want to briefly address developments on the regulatory fronts. After the recent release of the report on menthol by the Tobacco Products Scientific Advisory Committee, as well as reports from the industry and others, the FDA is now considering input from our range of parties in its review of the use of menthol cigarettes. R.J. Reynolds continue to believe that any final decision by the agency should be based on sound science, and the company will continue to provide information and perspectives on this issue to the agency as it undertakes this process. We remain committed to complying with FDA requirements as they are established, while continuing to compete effectively in the marketplace.
Now I'd like to talk about the highlights of R.J. Reynolds this first quarter. Adjusted operating income increased slightly as gains in the companies' growth of brand offset cigarette volume declines in its support and nonsupport brands. R.J. Reynolds adjusted operating margin also improved, driven by pricing and productivity gain. R.J. Reynolds long-term strategy to reduce complexity and improved efficiency is proven to be very successful. And the company plans to further refine its cigarette portfolio and eliminate most of its remaining private label brands this year you remember the company reduced its SKUs by over 80% through the end of last year to less than 150. R.J. Reynolds is also making good progress in improving its cigarette manufacturing efficiencies like consolidating production at its tobacco facility. The company remains on track to close its Whitaker Park manufacturing facility later this year.
R.J. Reynolds total first quarter cigarette market share was stable at 27.9%. However, if we exclude the delisted private label brands, the company's total cigarette market share actually increased by a full percentage point. As I mentioned earlier today, R.J. Reynolds growth brands, Camel and Pall Mall, continued to make gains in the first quarter. Their combined market share increased 2.7 percentage points to 16.3%. We remain pleased by Camel's performance, both in terms of market share and brand demographics.
The brand's first quarter cigarette market share increased by 0.07 of a percentage point from the prior-year quarter to 7.8%. And Camel launched a new equity building promotion, the Hump Day sweepstakes campaign at the end of March. Already, the brand is seeing a great response from consumers. This program is highlighted on Camel's packaging as being used in all major brand marketing materials. The promotion encourages adult tobacco consumers to seize the Hump Day and break free to explore the unexpected and get rewarded.
This is part of Camel's brands promise, to empower individual enjoyment for adult tobacco consumers. Also enhancing Camel's performance are its menthol styles, with innovative capsule technologies that offer adult smokers the choice, fresh and full flavor on demand. In fact, Camel's menthol share of market, including Camel Crush, increased 0.5 percentage points in the first quarter and now stands at 2%.
Moving to modern smoke-free tobacco. Camel introduced a number of changes in the quarter, all aimed at deepening the brand's commitment to offer innovative, smoke-free tobacco products for adult consumers to enjoy anytime and anywhere. For example, while Camel SNUS continues to show steady growth, R.J. Reynolds expanded the range of SNUS offerings during the quarter. To give even more adult tobacco consumers a reason to try and ultimately, switch to Camel SNUS. 
In February, Camel SNUS introduced Frost Large Pouches and a Mint style in selected lead markets. These new styles broaden the range of choices for adult tobacco consumers and generating good interest.
Camel SNUS Frost is the best-selling SNUS style in America, and the larger Frost Pouch styles will meet the preferences of a broader range of tobacco users. Camel SNUS Mint is another good addition to the portfolio, with Mint being the long-established preference in smokeless tobacco. With the introduction of an increasing number of competitive SNUS products over the past year, the SNUS category is continuing to expand. R.J. Reynolds expects this increase interest to further build positive for this category over the long-term. And Camel SNUS is well positioned to benefit from this growth.
In March, Camel's new line of dissolvable tobacco products, Orbs, Sticks and Strips were introduced in two new lead markets, Charlotte and Denver. These new dissolvable products and their packaging reflects the input of R.J. Reynolds received from consumers in the first round of lead markets. The company expects to continue to gain valuable insights from adult tobacco consumers in this new markets.
Now turning to R.J. Reynolds other growth brand, Pall Mall. Pall Mall had another outstanding quarter, increasing its market share by two percentage points from the prior-year quarter to 8.5%. The company remains focused on building the Pall Mall brand while balancing overall share and profitability growth. 
In summary, R.J. Reynolds continues its positive momentum in the first quarter, which provides a strong foundation for longer term success.
Turning to American Snuff. I'm very pleased with the company's results in the first quarter, with higher moist-snuff pricing and volume, delivering increases in the company's adjusted operating income and margin. Bear in mind that these results reflect only two months of earnings from Lane before that business was sold at the end of February. Once again, American Snuff's performance was led by its flagship brand, Grizzly, which continues to benefit from last year's packaging upgrade. Grizzly is also benefiting from the R.J. Reynolds field trade marketing organization that serves American Snuff. The company now has more than 2,000 trade and marketing professionals, representing its products at retail.
Turning to market share. The company's total moist-snuff offtake share increased 1.3 percentage points in the first quarter to 31.1%. And this growth was driven by Grizzly, which increases share by 1.5 percentage points to 27.1%. Grizzly's performance during the quarter was further enhanced by its strong positioning in Pouch sales. In the first quarter, more than 9% of total moist-snuff category sales were in the rapidly growing Pouch segment, and Grizzly groups represent about 25% of that total. That's great progress considering that the brand introduced its first Pouch style product just three years ago.
I'm pleased to report that Grizzly now has the number one overall projects by in the market. I must say that despite intense competitive activity, Grizzly has had a powerful impact since it was introduced 10 years ago, and that's still with only 12 styles.
I'd also like to mention the new retail moist muff contract that American Snuff introduced in February. These contracts represent an investment in the business and ensures that Grizzly will have it's fair share of retail space, as well as improved pricing and brand communication.
This investment will better position Grizzly for continued long-term growth. So it's clear that both American Snuff and R.J. Reynolds are focused on delivering profitable growth for RAI shareholders. And I'm extremely pleased with the momentum. Now Tom will provide some financial details. Tom?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan. Good morning, everyone. During my discussion, I'll focus primarily on adjusted results to provide perspective on our underlying business performance. Reconciliations of adjusted to reported results are in our press release, which is availa
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan. Good morning, everyone. During my discussion, I'll focus primarily on adjusted results to provide perspective on our underlying business performance. Reconciliations of adjusted to reported results are in our press release, which is available on our website.
Turning to our financial highlights. RAI's first quarter adjusted earnings per share increased by 0.4% to $0.59. These adjusted results exclude the $0.01 per share related to plant closings and tax items. On a reported basis, RAI's first quarter EPS was $0.60, that was more than triple the prior year quarter's reported EPS of $0.14, which was impacted by the changes in Federal healthcare laws and the Canadian government settlements. RAI's adjusted operating margin saw strong growth in the first quarter, gaining 0.09 of a percentage point to 29.6%. As a result of this performance, I'm pleased to reaffirm adjusted 2011 EPS guidance in the range of $2.60 to $2.70, excluding implementation costs related to plant closings and tax items.
I would note that delaying sale closed earlier than our original expectations of mid year which will result in a lower earnings contribution from that business that we have previously estimated.
Turning to R.J. Reynolds performance. RJ Reynolds' first quarter adjusted operating income of $471 million increased slightly from the prior-year quarter. The company benefited from higher cigarette pricing and growth brand volume gains, while also delivering further productivity improvements. This adjusted results exclude $8 million in implementation costs related to plant closings.
And R.J. Reynolds also improved its first quarter adjusted operating margin, which increased 0.5 percentage points to 27.8%. 
Turning to cigarette shipment volume. R.J. Reynolds first quarter cigarette shipment volume declined 5.2% from the prior-year quarter. However, excluding the delisted private label brands, volume was down 3%. This compares well with the industries first quarter volume decline of 3.4%.
I would also note that R.J. Reynolds' wholesale inventory levels declined about 300 million units during the quarter, while industry inventories remained constant at relatively higher levels. So that's a brief recap of R.J. Reynolds key results.
On American Snuff, given the impact on earnings from the sale Of Lane, American Snuff delivered solid first quarter growth, with adjusted operating income increasing 4.2% from the prior-year quarter to $87 million. This was driven by higher pricing and moist-snuff volume growth. These adjusted results exclude $2 million of implementation costs.
American Snuff's first quarter adjusted operating margin also increased, gaining 0.5 percentage points from the prior-year quarter to 52.3%.
Turning to moist-snuff volume. The company's total first quarter shipment volume grew 13.2%. I would note that this reflects a favorable comparison with the prior-year quarter, which was impacted by aggressive competitive activity. Grizzly's first quarter shipment volume saw a significant increase, rising 17.1% from the prior-year quarter. So American Snuff continues to build on the strong foundation and is well positioned for growth over the rest of the year. 
Turning to our balance sheet. Reynolds American ended the quarter with cash balances of $3 billion, including the $200 million from the Lane sales. I'll remind you that on April 15, R.J. Reynolds made its MSA [ph] payment of about $2 billion, of which $477 million was deposited in the NPM disputed funds account. That brings the total amount in dispute to almost $3 billion for the years 2003 through 2008. We continue to evaluate opportunities to add value for our shareholders. With the 8.2% dividend increase in February, RAI has raised dividend by nearly 18% over the past year.
Thank you, and we'll now turn to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you remind our callers how to get into the queue?

componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, you're right. I mean we've obviously got the MSA payment behind us. I would remind you that I have in the past on these calls, we're building two facilities at American Snuff. The processing facility, as well as new manufacturing facility in Me
componenttext: Okay. Yes, you're right. I mean we've obviously got the MSA payment behind us. I would remind you that I have in the past on these calls, we're building two facilities at American Snuff. The processing facility, as well as new manufacturing facility in Memphis. Our capital expenditures this year, we expect to be in the range where they were last year. And that's right around $200 million. We spent $44 million  of that in the first quarter. So we still have a little bit lifting to do there. We've got some debt coming due in June, $400 million, and that's our floater, that's at about 1%. And so we would likely pay that off in cash. So that it's refinancing that because refinancing will be dilutive to our results. That having been said, we are focused on getting value back to shareholders. In my remarks, I mentioned that we have increased the dividend almost 18% in the past year. We look at that as the primary vehicle to getting value back. But we also do discuss share repurchases, and we will continue to have these discussions but internally and with our Board.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, Dan, if I can ask a quick question on underlying cigarette consumption. It seems like, down 3% is kind of where it should be down to 3% to 4%. Gas prices are much higher. Just curious on your take on kind of what's going on in the marketp
componenttext: Great. And then, Dan, if I can ask a quick question on underlying cigarette consumption. It seems like, down 3% is kind of where it should be down to 3% to 4%. Gas prices are much higher. Just curious on your take on kind of what's going on in the marketplace in terms of consumption. Actually surprisingly is a state given what's going on in terms of inflation for the lower end consumer. Is there an income or employment situation going on here where low income jobs or starting to come back in the marketplace and that's kind of helping offset it? Any perspective will be useful.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nik. I don't think we've really seen a change in trend really over the last quarters. Of course, a lot of the economic recession on employment that and so fourth has already been factored into some of the trends. Of course, we need to watch and see w
componenttext: Yes, Nik. I don't think we've really seen a change in trend really over the last quarters. Of course, a lot of the economic recession on employment that and so fourth has already been factored into some of the trends. Of course, we need to watch and see what happens with the more recent spike in gas prices, in terms of what that does in disposable income. The way I like to look at kind of the total market development there, appears to be sort of a level where secular decline in cigarettes, specifically. That number's probably somewhere about 1.8 to 2 and what that really means is absent any pricing, that's what the decline rate would be. And on top of that, that would put the price sensitivity in demand. That historically of about 0.35. And we haven't really seen any change in trend based on short-term economic factors that to that model.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011

componenttext: I don't think to a great degree. There's a number of different things actually happen and sort of embedded within that number. When you compare back to the first quarter last year, I would say that from a promotion point of view, we were slightly uncompetitive in the marketplace. Vis-a-vis sort of normalized quarters. And I would characterize this last quarter, first quarter this year being sort of quite normalized to level of spending. So I think when you do that analysis, it's partly the base quarter that you're comparing to. But I'm actually quite happy with the pricing growth that we've had year-on-year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: David, let me answer that question really in two ways. There's appropriate is a real hard word to define because it's all relative to competition. And I think, relative to competition, I think things were pretty much in balance in the first quarter. But I
componenttext: David, let me answer that question really in two ways. There's appropriate is a real hard word to define because it's all relative to competition. And I think, relative to competition, I think things were pretty much in balance in the first quarter. But I think when we start looking at those kind of revenue and pricing kind of metrics on a year-over-year you basis, I think there are other things at play. I think partly, there were some of the inventory dynamics which we've talked about but more specifically, it's how competitive we are we in the same quarter last year vis-a-vis this year. And when we look at that quarter last year, I think we were slightly light or slightly spending a little bit less than we might have wanted to because it's a balance that we're trying to find between volume, market share and profitability. And I would characterize this last quarter is being fairly normative.
